senses.de: to take part in something or start doing it.
senses.ex: The students engaged in a group discussion.

Tips.title: Active Participation
Tips.description: Use to emphasize active involvement in an activity, not just being present.
Tips.example: He engaged wholeheartedly in the charity work.

Tips.title: Group Activities
Tips.description: Often used with activities involving multiple people working together.
Tips.example: They engaged in a community project.

Tips.title: Voluntary Action
Tips.description: Implies that the action is taken willingly or by choice.

senses.de: to hire someone and make them promise to work for you.
senses.ex: I engaged a lawyer to handle my case.

Tips.title: Professional Service
Tips.description: Use when you formally agree to hire someone for their services.
Tips.example: The company engaged an accountant for the audit.

Tips.title: Legal Implications
Tips.description: Points to a professional commitment that might have legal backing.
Tips.example: They engaged a contractor with a signed agreement.

senses.de: to keep a person interested or focused on something.
senses.ex: A good teacher engages the students in the learning process.

Tips.title: Sustained Attention
Tips.description: Highlights the ongoing nature of holding someone's interest.
Tips.example: Her storytelling engaged the children for hours.

Tips.title: Engagement Quality
Tips.description: Refers to the depth of attention and interest of the engaged parties.
Tips.example: His speech engaged even the most distracted listeners.

senses.de: to enter into conflict or combat with, usually a formal one.
senses.ex: The army was ordered to engage the enemy.

Tips.title: Commit to Conflict
Tips.description: Describes a deliberate decision to enter into a fight or struggle.
Tips.example: The knights engaged their foes valiantly.

Tips.title: Military Context
Tips.description: Typically used to refer to military confrontations.
Tips.example: The troops prepared to engage at dawn.

senses.de: to bind oneself, as by a promise or contract.

Tips.title: Personal Commitment
Tips.description: Indicates a promise between individuals, especially in personal relationships.
Tips.example: They engaged to stay faithful to each other.

Tips.title: Formal Promise
Tips.description: Suggests a formal or solemn commitment, often public.
Tips.example: She engaged to volunteer at the hospital.

Attract.wordDefinition:
Attract means to draw someone's attention towards you or something.

It describes the initial phase of getting someone interested in something or someone. For example, a company might attract customers by using catchy advertisements or offering discounts.

In simpler words, attract is like getting someone's attention, while engage is like keeping them interested and involved.

Commit.wordDefinition:
Commit implies making a promise or obligation to oneself or to others to complete a task or to act on something.

For example, a student may commit to studying for an exam, meaning they promise to put in the time and effort required to prepare for it.

Commit means making a promise or obligation, whereas engage means actively participating or involving oneself in something.

Enlist.wordDefinition:
Enlist means to sign up or join something, usually for a specific purpose. For example, you can enlist in the army or enlist in a club.

Both words involve some sort of involvement, but engage is more casual and voluntary, while enlist is more formal and structured.

Engage can be used in many contexts, while enlist is more commonly used in military, organizational or institutional settings.

Entertain.wordDefinition:
Engage means to involve or participate in, while entertain means to provide enjoyment or amusement.

Entertain is used when someone or something is providing enjoyment or amusement to others. It is applicable in situations where there is a need to relax, have fun or simply pass the time.

For example, watching a comedy movie or attending a live music concert can be considered as entertainment.

Hire.wordDefinition:
Engage means to involve someone in a task or activity, whereas the word hire means to pay someone for their services for a specific task or job.

However, if you hired a friend to help you with a project, you would be paying them for their work.

Engage is more commonly used in casual or collaborative situations, while hire is used in professional or employment situations.

Interest.wordDefinition:
Interest means to attract someone's attention or curiosity towards something. For example, if you are interested in music, you are curious and attracted to it.

Both words have different applications. Engage is applicable when you want to involve someone in a specific activity, while Interest is applicable when you want to attract someone's attention to something.

For example, a teacher may engage her students in a group activity to help them learn better. An advertisement may try to interest people in buying a particular product.

Involve.wordDefinition:
Engage means to participate or be involved in something actively or to involve someone in a conversation, whereas involve means to include or affect someone or something in a particular situation or activity.

If you are involved in a project, it means that you are playing a role or contributing to the project. Alternatively, if you are involved in a dispute, it means that you are a part of the dispute and may be affected by its outcome.

Engage relates more to active participation, while involve relates more to being affected or included in something.

Occupy.wordDefinition:
Occupy means to fill up or take up space, time or attention. It is applicable when something is taking up a physical or mental space that could be used for other things.

For example, you can engage in a conversation with your friend or engage in a sport like basketball. Whereas, you can occupy a seat on a bus or occupy your time with a hobby like reading.

Participate.wordDefinition:
Participate means to take part in something. When you participate in something, you are involved in an activity or event, but you may not necessarily be actively engaged or interacting.

For example, you can participate in a marathon by running along with other participants, even if you are not engaging in conversation or actively interacting with them.

To engage means to actively involve oneself, while to participate means to take part in something. Engage is applicable when you want to be actively involved in something and interact with it, while participate is applicable when you want to be involved in an activity but may not necessarily be actively engaged.

videos.Text: Playing a musical instrument engages practically every area of the brain at once, especially the visual, auditory, and motor cortices. As with any other workout, disciplined, structured practice in playing music strengthens those brain functions, allowing us to apply that strength to other activities.

quotes.Text: The truth is that there is no actual stress or anxiety in the world; it's your thoughts that create these false beliefs. You can't package stress, touch it, or see it. There are only people engaged in stressful thinking.
quotes.Title: American Psychologist
quotes.Name: Wayne Dyer

quotes.Text: In the village where I grew up, a lot of girls didn't have a choice of whether to go to middle school. They would get engaged or married and spend their entire life in that village.
quotes.Title: Chinese Businesswoman
quotes.Name: Zhou Qunfei

quotes.Text: What I have never been afraid of is to be a little silly, and you can engage people that way. My view is, first you get them to laugh, then you get them to listen.
quotes.Title: American First Lady
quotes.Name: Michelle Obama

quotes.Text: My marriage is incredibly important to me. It's the place from which I engage in the world every day, and the place to which I return every day.
quotes.Title: American Celebrity
quotes.Name: Chelsea Clinton

quotes.Text: I do enjoy fielding in the deep and I enjoy engaging with the crowd.
quotes.Title: English Athlete
quotes.Name: Jonny Bairstow

quotes.Text: It's really important to stay engaged and involved in the character.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: David Ogden Stiers

quotes.Text: I want an audience that's passionate, that can be engaged.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: David Brock

quotes.Text: I've always been engaged in social protection programmes.
quotes.Title: South Korean Public Servant
quotes.Name: Jim Yong Kim

quotes.Text: Audiences need to engage with characters.
quotes.Title: American Businesswoman
quotes.Name: Nina Tassler

quotes.Text: Not engaging in ignorance is wisdom.
quotes.Title: Indian Leader
quotes.Name: Bodhidharma
